Award.AwardTitle: CareerWise III: Intersectional Perspectives on Perceived Supports & Persistence Among Diverse Women in STEM Doctoral Programs

Division.LongName: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

Award.AbstractNarration: This study will investigate the associations between perceived supports and persistence for both majority (Caucasian) women and underrepresented minority (URM) women in STEM doctoral programs. Women leave doctoral programs in STEM at higher rates than their white male counterparts. Reducing the attrition of these talented individuals from STEM is of particular importance given that diversity at all levels of the STEM workforce has been shown to benefit the outcomes of related scientific research. The proposed work will increase understanding of the reasons for the underrepresentation of women in STEM academic and research careers. Key research findings will be incorporated in the online CareerWISE resilience training intervention and will provide the foundation for informing and educating key support sources about how to strengthen support for women in STEM.<br/><br/>The project addresses the overarching research question of: How do experiences of perceived support play a role in the academic persistence of diverse female doctoral students in STEM? The project proposes three studies, each of which utilizes different research methods, and are guided by the theoretical lens of Social Cognitive Career Theory. The "reflections study" will produce qualitative data about the nature of support episodes, and the sources, types, and timing of interpersonal support that were most effective in mitigating discouragement and stresses from difficulties experienced in STEM doctoral programs. The lab-based "communications of support" study will provide real-time observations of how support is communicated between a faculty mentor and an advanced stage doctoral student. Finally, the "first and second year support experiences" study will assess support experiences that take place during the critical early stages of doctoral study. Participants in the studies will include current STEM doctoral students, early career professionals who have recently graduated from doctoral programs, and women who left their STEM doctoral programs prior to completing their degrees. Data across the studies will be collected from interviews, surveys, daily journals, and lab-based observation. The project is supported by the Education and Human Resources Core Research Program (ECR), which funds fundamental research in STEM learning and learning environments, broadening participation in STEM, and STEM workforce development.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

ProgramReference.Text: GSE: Research on Gender in S&E

POR.DRECONTENT:
The CareerWISE research program strives to expand our understanding of the experiences of and potent forms of support for diverse women in science, technology, engineering, and math (STEM) PhD programs and identify effective actions that faculty, administrators, and the women themselves can take to strengthen persistence toward degree completion.  This specific project, titled ?CareerWise III: Intersectional Perspectives on Perceived Supports & Persistence Among Diverse Women in STEM Doctoral Programs'' (NSF grants 2019533 and 1761278) was funded for three years with $940,000, shared by a research team comprised of faculty and graduate students at  Arizona State University and the University of Massachusetts Boston.  


We focused on trying to understand how interpersonal support (from faculty, other students, family, etc.) influences the experiences of Women of Color (for example, Black Latina,  and Multi-Racial women), and white women who are pursuing their doctoral degrees in a STEM field. Our team and the NSF were interested in this study because much other research has documented that women (and particularly Women of Color) are choosing not to pursue doctorates in STEM as frequently as men. And, those that do choose to pursue their doctoral programs are leaving before completing their degrees.  Reasons for the lack of enrollment and premature departures include the presence of discriminatory and exclusionary practices that are systemically embedded  within the culture of graduate programs within STEM.  Our research on this project builds on those findings to explore how and whether key sources of interpersonal support can mitigate the impact of these negative experiences on the wellbeing decisions around degree completion among women doctoral students in STEM.  

 

Our project outcomes were informed by three studies that included a variety of data collection approaches.  We  interviewed Women of Color and white women about their prior experiences of interpersonal support (or lack thereof) within their STEM doctoral programs, and we observed real time conversations among women doctoral students and their advisors.   We also surveyed hundreds of women on the climate and culture of their STEM doctoral programs, their mental health, their interpersonal relationships and support, and their plans related to completing (or not) their doctorate degrees.  Finally, we collected data twice a week for eight weeks from more than 100 women (60 Women of Color and 40 white women) about their mental health, the challenges they had experienced since the previous data collection, and the support they sought out and received in response to those challenges. 

 

We found that challenging encounters within their graduate school environments contributed to increased stress, depression, anxiety, and suicidal ideation among Black, Latina, and white graduate women in STEM. Subsequently, these same experiences contributed to a reduced desire (and intention) to complete their doctoral programs.  Relatedly, we found that Women of Color who reported more frequent experiences with stress arising from sexism and racism felt less like they belonged within their program and reported lower quality relationships with their advisors.  

 

The importance of the advisor-advisee relationship was salient across all studies.  The negative impact of both academic challenges (e.g., research challenges or challenges with coursework) and personal challenges (e.g., health issues, childcare, or financial issues) were mitigated (or exacerbated) by support (or lack thereof) from advisors. Additionally, in observed conversations between advisors and advisees, less supportive conversations were found to focus on the advisor rather than the doctoral student advisee, ignored social identities (e.g., race or gender) of the advisee, were considered patronizing by the advisee, and included instances of advisor credit taking.  

By increasing our understanding of the ways in which support is perceived to be most effective among Women of Color and white women doctoral students in STEM, the outcomes of this project will positively impact the educational experiences, wellbeing,  and persistence decisions of future women doctoral students in STEM. The findings from this project also have the potential to disrupt systemic sexism and racism within our education systems to broaden the participation and promote greater wellbeing among doctoral women in fields beyond STEM.

We have added our findings to our CareerWISE online resilience training website (https://careerwise.asu.edu), which provides a different avenue for informing and educating relevant stakeholders about effective ways to support white women and Women of Color enrolled in STEM doctoral programs. The website, now available to the public, speaks more directly to the experiences of WOC in STEM and serves as a foundation for informing and educating relevant stakeholders about effective ways to support diverse women in STEM doctoral programs.  Screenshots from the website are included with this report.
